elements.content: Thermal stability, structural evolution pathways, and phase transition mechanisms of the calcium oxalates whewellite (CaC2O4­·H2O), weddellite (CaC2O4­·(2+x)­H2O), and caoxite (CaC2O4­·3H2O) have been analyzed using single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). During single crystal XRD heating experiments, α-CaC2O4 and the novel calcium oxalate monohydrate have been obtained and structurally characterized for the first time. The highest thermal expansion of these compounds is observed along the direction of the hydrogen bonds, whereas the lowest expansion and even contraction of the structures occur due to the displacement of neighbor layered complexes toward each other and to an orthogonalization of the monoclinic angles. Within the calcium oxalate family, whewellite should be regarded as the most stable crystalline phase at ambient conditions. Weddellite and caoxite transform to whewellite during dehydration-driven phase transition promoted by time and/or heating.

During single crystal XRD heating experiments, α-CaC2O4 and the novel calcium oxalate monohydrate have been obtained and structurally characterized for the first time. The highest thermal expansion of these compounds is observed along the direction of the hydrogen bonds, whereas the lowest expansion and even contraction of the structures occur due to the displacement of neighbor layered complexes toward each other and to an orthogonalization of the monoclinic angles. Within the calcium oxalate family, whewellite should be regarded as the most stable crystalline phase at ambient conditions. Weddellite and caoxite transform to whewellite during dehydration-driven phase transition promoted by time and/or heating.

elements.content: Oxalic acid is the smallest and simplest dicarboxylate and is ubiquitous in the environment (in soil, water, and aerosols), which explains the widespread distribution of oxalates. Calcium oxalates are notably common biominerals and can be found, e.g., in coal basins, bituminous shale, bottom sediments, on the contact of rocks with guano, lichens, fungi, or some higher plants, and even on a surface of monuments. This is mostly due to the affinity of oxalates to bivalent cations, which is reflected in the ability to form insoluble precipitates, and because the sources of calcium (carbonate rocks and subfossils) interact more actively with weak organic acids. Calcium oxalates are also found among the pathogenic mineral precipitates in human bone marrow, myocardium, joints, lungs, liver, thyroid gland, intestinal mucosa, eyes, and urinary system. Oxalates span therefore several fields (medicine, biology, mineralogy, materials science, etc.), which is reflected in a large number of publications. Nevertheless, many questions remain unresolved. For instance, the role of water in the formation of calcium oxalate crystal structures as well as the mechanisms of phase transition is still unclear.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Oxalic acid is the smallest and simplest dicarboxylate and is ubiquitous in the environment (in soil, water, and aerosols), which explains the widespread distribution of oxalates. Calcium oxalates are notably common biominerals and can be found, e.g., in coal basins, bituminous shale, bottom sediments, on the contact of rocks with guano, lichens, fungi, or some higher plants, and even on a surface of monuments. This is mostly due to the affinity of oxalates to bivalent cations, which is reflected in the ability to form insoluble precipitates, and because the sources of calcium (carbonate rocks and subfossils) interact more actively with weak organic acids. Calcium oxalates are also found among the pathogenic mineral precipitates in human bone marrow, myocardium, joints, lungs, liver, thyroid gland, intestinal mucosa, eyes, and urinary system. Oxalates span therefore several fields (medicine, biology, mineralogy, materials science, etc.), which is reflected in a large number of publications. Nevertheless, many questions remain unresolved. For instance, the role of water in the formation of calcium oxalate crystal structures as well as the mechanisms of phase transition is still unclear.

elements.content: Calcium oxalates are represented in nature by three hydrated forms: whewellite (CaC2O4·H2O; COM), weddellite (CaC2O4·(2+x)­H2O; COD), and caoxite (CaC2O4·3H2O; COT). The anhydrous forms are known only as synthetic compounds, so the H2O molecules obviously play a significant role in crystal growth. COM is the most prevalent mineral, while COD and COT are regarded as metastable phases, which is confirmed by a number of studies and observations. On the other hand, COD and COT are regarded as precursors for COM crystals formation. Thus, the composition of oxalate renal stones varies during storage at room temperature. For instance, pure COD samples of our collection after 4 years of storage contain, on average, about 30% of COM. A similar example was recently described in Conti et al. 2015; as a result, we can say that any aged caoxite crystal in museums or private collections is most likely not COT, but other calcium oxalates.

The anhydrous forms are known only as synthetic compounds, so the H2O molecules obviously play a significant role in crystal growth. COM is the most prevalent mineral, while COD and COT are regarded as metastable phases, which is confirmed by a number of studies and observations. On the other hand, COD and COT are regarded as precursors for COM crystals formation. Thus, the composition of oxalate renal stones varies during storage at room temperature. For instance, pure COD samples of our collection after 4 years of storage contain, on average, about 30% of COM. A similar example was recently described in Conti et al. 2015; as a result, we can say that any aged caoxite crystal in museums or private collections is most likely not COT, but other calcium oxalates.

elements.content: A number of works have also been devoted to the dehydration of calcium oxalates, but they mainly rely on thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), or scanning electron microscopy (SEM). These techniques are very sensitive to changes in the amount of water, but at the same time, they give a very rough idea of the state of crystalline matter, which is often the priority.

elements.content: Crystal structures of hydrated calcium oxalates were intensively studied during the last half a century, and results are summarized in . However, there is still no clear understanding about the correlation between the structural architectures of the calcium oxalates. Thus, it is quite essential to determine the ways of dehydration-driven structural evolution and phase transition mechanisms among the aforementioned compounds.

Herein we report on the thermal stability of crystalline compounds and phase transition mechanisms within the family of calcium oxalates, which shows a highly complex nature for such a chemically simple system. During single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) heating experiments α-CaC2O4 and the novel calcium oxalate monohydrate has been obtained and structurally characterized.

elements.content: Single crystals of COM and COD have been extracted from the oxalic renal stones of our collection, which consist of about 2000 samples removed from residents of St. Petersburg, Russian Federation. About 74.5% of samples within the collection consist of calcium oxalates and about 2% are pure weddellite stones. A fraction of the pure COM and COD stones () was also crushed for the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments at nonambient temperatures. No natural COT was found.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Calcium Oxalate Crystalline Samples

Single crystals of COM and COD have been extracted from the oxalic renal stones of our collection, which consist of about 2000 samples removed from residents of St. Petersburg, Russian Federation. About 74.5% of samples within the collection consist of calcium oxalates and about 2% are pure weddellite stones. A fraction of the pure COM and COD stones () was also crushed for the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments at nonambient temperatures. No natural COT was found.

elements.content: Calcium oxalate crystals and renal stones: fragments of the whewellite monophase renal stone (a); single crystals of weddellite (b, c); twin of caoxite crystals (d); caoxite crystal after measurement at 40 °C (e; the loss of transparency is due to the phase transition to compound 14, Table ); weddellite renal stone (f; the surface of the stone is formed by sharp edges and smooth, reflecting the light, faces of COD crystals).
elements.clean_text: 1  Calcium oxalate crystals and renal stones: fragments of the whewellite monophase renal stone (a); single crystals of weddellite (b, c); twin of caoxite crystals (d); caoxite crystal after measurement at 40 °C (e; the loss of transparency is due to the phase transition to compound 14, Table  ); weddellite renal stone (f; the surface of the stone is formed by sharp edges and smooth, reflecting the light, faces of COD crystals).

elements.content: COM, COD, and COT were also synthesized from sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4, 98%, Vekton), anhydrous calcium chloride (CaCl2, 99%, Vekton), citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·H2O, 99%, Vekton), magnesium sulfate heptahydrate (MgSO4·7H2O, 99%, Vekton), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99%, Vekton), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 35–38 wt % in H2O, 99.9%, Vekton). The synthesis was performed at room temperature (22–25 °C) by precipitation from aqueous solutions of the correspondent reagents in 500 mL of deionized water at different pH values in the range 4.5–7.5). The solutions were kept for 5 days to complete the precipitation. The pH was adjusted using sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid solutions. The resulting precipitates were filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried in air at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: COM, COD, and COT were also synthesized from sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4, 98%, Vekton), anhydrous calcium chloride (CaCl2, 99%, Vekton), citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7⋅H2O, 99%, Vekton), magnesium sulfate heptahydrate (MgSO4⋅7H2O, 99%, Vekton), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99%, Vekton), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 35-38 wt % in H2O, 99.9%, Vekton). The synthesis was performed at room temperature (22-25 °C) by precipitation from aqueous solutions of the correspondent reagents in 500 mL of deionized water at different pH values in the range 4.5-7.5). The solutions were kept for 5 days to complete the precipitation. The pH was adjusted using sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid solutions. The resulting precipitates were filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried in air at room temperature.

elements.content: In particular, the COM powder was synthesized by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.268 g (2 mmol) of sodium oxalate and 0.222 g (2 mmol) of calcium chloride at a pH range of 5.50–5.65. Conversely, a crystalline powder of predominantly COD (with minor amounts of COM) was prepared by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.201 g (1.5 mmol) of sodium oxalate and 0.833 g (7.5 mmol) of calcium chloride with addition of 0.672 g (3.2 mmol) of citric acid at a pH range of 5.95–6.15. Finally, single crystals of COT were prepared by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.201 g (1.5 mmol) of sodium oxalate, 0.666 g (6.0 mmol) of calcium chloride with addition of 1.365 g (6.5 mmol) of citric acid and 0.246 g (1.0 mmol) of magnesium sulfate at a pH range of 5.95–6.15. The major portion of the obtained precipitate consisted of a mixture of COM spherulites (up to 20–30 μm) and bipyramidal crystals of COD (up to 50 μm), while the minor portion of precipitate consisted of larger sized (up to 200 μm, ) prismatic crystals of COT, which were manually selected under the optical microscope.
elements.clean_text: In particular, the COM powder was synthesized by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.268 g (2 mmol) of sodium oxalate and 0.222 g (2 mmol) of calcium chloride at a pH range of 5.50-5.65. Conversely, a crystalline powder of predominantly COD (with minor amounts of COM) was prepared by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.201 g (1.5 mmol) of sodium oxalate and 0.833 g (7.5 mmol) of calcium chloride with addition of 0.672 g (3.2 mmol) of citric acid at a pH range of 5.95-6.15. Finally, single crystals of COT were prepared by precipitation from aqueous solution of 0.201 g (1.5 mmol) of sodium oxalate, 0.666 g (6.0 mmol) of calcium chloride with addition of 1.365 g (6.5 mmol) of citric acid and 0.246 g (1.0 mmol) of magnesium sulfate at a pH range of 5.95-6.15. The major portion of the obtained precipitate consisted of a mixture of COM spherulites (up to 20-30 μm) and bipyramidal crystals of COD (up to 50 μm), while the minor portion of precipitate consisted of larger sized (up to 200 μm, ) prismatic crystals of COT, which were manually selected under the optical microscope.

elements.content: Single crystals of COM, COD, and COT were selected under an optical microscope, encased in oil-based cryoprotectant, and mounted on glass fibers. Data were collected using a Rigaku Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur diffractometer equipped with an Eos CCD area detector operated with monochromated MoKα radiation (λ­[MoKα] = 0.71073 Å) at 50 kV and 40 mA. Diffraction data were collected at different temperatures in the range −173 to +100 °C () with frame widths of 0.5° in ω and φ, and exposures of 30, 5, and 3 s spent per each frame within the series of measurements of COM, COD, and COT initial crystals, respectively. Data were integrated and corrected for background, Lorentz, and polarization effects. An empirical absorption correction based on spherical harmonics implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK algorithm was applied in CrysAlisPro program. The unit-cell parameters ( and S1) were refined by the least-squares techniques. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using the SHELX programs incorporated in the OLEX2 program package. The final models included coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. The H atoms of H2O molecules were localized from difference Fourier maps and kept fixed during the refinement. The positions of the H atoms of COD “zeolite” H2O molecules were not localized. Supplementary crystallographic data have been deposited in the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database () and can be obtained from Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe via www.fiz-karlsruhe.de/en/leistungen/kristallographie/kristallstrukturdepot/order-form-request-for-deposited-data.html.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Studies

Single crystals of COM, COD, and COT were selected under an optical microscope, encased in oil-based cryoprotectant, and mounted on glass fibers. Data were collected using a Rigaku Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur diffractometer equipped with an Eos CCD area detector operated with monochromated MoKα radiation (λ[MoKα] = 0.71073 Å) at 50 kV and 40 mA. Diffraction data were collected at different temperatures in the range -173 to +100 °C () with frame widths of 0.5° in ω and φ, and exposures of 30, 5, and 3 s spent per each frame within the series of measurements of COM, COD, and COT initial crystals, respectively. Data were integrated and corrected for background, Lorentz, and polarization effects. An empirical absorption correction based on spherical harmonics implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK algorithm was applied in CrysAlisPro program. The unit-cell parameters ( and S1) were refined by the least-squares techniques. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using the SHELX programs incorporated in the OLEX2 program package. The final models included coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. The H atoms of H2O molecules were localized from difference Fourier maps and kept fixed during the refinement. The positions of the H atoms of COD "zeolite" H2O molecules were not localized. Supplementary crystallographic data have been deposited in the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database () and can be obtained from Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe via www.fiz-karlsruhe.de/en/leistungen/kristallographie/kristallstrukturdepot/order-form-request-for-deposited-data.html.

Pieces of monomineral COM and COD renal stones, as well as synthetic samples of hydrated calcium oxalates, were ground in an agate mortar for the in situ examination using a Rigaku Ultima IV powder X-ray diffractometer (CoKα radiation; 40 kV/30 mA; Bragg–Brentano geometry; PSD D-Tex Ultra detector). A Rigaku SHT-1500 chamber was employed for experiments in air in the range of +25 to +150 °C; a Pt strip (20 × 12 × 2 mm3) was used as heating element and sample holder. Low-temperature experiments (−173 to +170 °C) were performed in a vacuum in a Rigaku R 300 chamber using a Cu sample holder (20 × 12 × 2 mm3). The temperature steps varied from 2 to 10 °C depending on compound and temperature range. The heating rate was 2 °C/min. The collection time at each temperature step was about 30 min. The reversibility of the observed phase transformations was checked by collecting PXRD data both on heating and cooling.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Studies at Nonambient Temperatures

Pieces of monomineral COM and COD renal stones, as well as synthetic samples of hydrated calcium oxalates, were ground in an agate mortar for the in situ examination using a Rigaku Ultima IV powder X-ray diffractometer (CoKα radiation; 40 kV/30 mA; Bragg-Brentano geometry; PSD D-Tex Ultra detector). A Rigaku SHT-1500 chamber was employed for experiments in air in the range of +25 to +150 °C; a Pt strip (20 × 12 × 2 mm3) was used as heating element and sample holder. Low-temperature experiments (-173 to +170 °C) were performed in a vacuum in a Rigaku R 300 chamber using a Cu sample holder (20 × 12 × 2 mm3). The temperature steps varied from 2 to 10 °C depending on compound and temperature range. The heating rate was 2 °C/min. The collection time at each temperature step was about 30 min. The reversibility of the observed phase transformations was checked by collecting PXRD data both on heating and cooling.

elements.content: Phase identification was carried out using the ICDD PDF-2 Database (release 2016). The unit cell parameters were refined by the Pawley method using TOPAS 4.2 software. The background was modeled using a Chebychev polynomial of 12th order. The peak profile was described using the fundamental parameters approach. The zero shift parameter was refined at every step, and it was usually increased by 0.01–0.02°2θ because of the sample holder expansion on heating.
elements.clean_text: Phase identification was carried out using the ICDD PDF-2 Database (release 2016). The unit cell parameters were refined by the Pawley method using TOPAS 4.2 software. The background was modeled using a Chebychev polynomial of 12th order. The peak profile was described using the fundamental parameters approach. The zero shift parameter was refined at every step, and it was usually increased by 0.01-0.02°2θ because of the sample holder expansion on heating.

elements.content: The main coefficients of the thermal-expansion tensor were determined using a second-order approximation of temperature dependencies for the unit cell parameters by means of the TEV program. The same software was also employed to determine the orientation of the principal axes of the thermal expansion tensor and for visualization purposes.

The same software was also employed to determine the orientation of the principal axes of the thermal expansion tensor and for visualization purposes.

elements.content: The first investigation of whewellite crystal structure was performed by Cocco. Afterward, the structural model of COM was refined several times either in P21/c or P21/n space groups. The works of Deganello on thermal treatment of whewellite crystals should be noted.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Structure Descriptions

Whewellite Structure Evolution

The first investigation of whewellite crystal structure was performed by Cocco. Afterward, the structural model of COM was refined several times either in P21/c or P21/n space groups. The works of Deganello on thermal treatment of whewellite crystals should be noted.

elements.content: The crystal structure of COM (1–3) is based on Ca-bearing sheets, arranged parallel to (100) in the case of whewellite structure (1 and 2; a), and parallel to (101) in the case of its high-temperature modification (3; b). The Ca2+ cations are arranged at the center of a distorted square antiprism that shares edges with three adjacent antiprisms to form layers with lens-like voids, occupied by the oxalate groups. These layers are linked to each other via oxalate groups and hydrogen bonds, which involve terminal H2O molecules of Ca polyhedra that are directed to the interlayer space. There are two crystallographically nonequivalent Ca positions in the structure of whewellite (1 and 2), which are coordinated by eight O atoms that belong to one H2O molecule and five oxalate groups. H2O molecules in the structures of 1 and 2 occupy two sites, each of which is disordered over two crystallographically nonequivalent positions (a) with the total site occupancy factor (s.o.f.) equal to 1.0. The Ca–O distances vary in the range 2.425(2)–2.527(3) Å with an average value equal, respectively, to 2.426 and 2.447 Å for the Ca1- and Ca2-centered polyhedra in the structure of 2.

These layers are linked to each other via oxalate groups and hydrogen bonds, which involve terminal H2O molecules of Ca polyhedra that are directed to the interlayer space. Legend: Ca-polyhedra = lilac; O atoms = red; C atoms = white; H atoms = gray.

elements.content: HT modification of whewellite (3) possess the same structural motif as in 1 and 2, and even symmetry remains monoclinic; however, the lattice type changes from primitive to I-centered and the b unit cell parameter halves (). These changes are the result of slight temperature-induced atomic shifts that make the Ca polyhedra and oxalate groups arranged right one after another on the projection along the [010] in comparison to those for whewellite (a,c). Such structural transformation can hardly be followed using PXRD due to the high similarity of the experimental patterns (c and S1), but is well seen on the unwrapped precession images of the reciprocal space (a,b): extinction of reflections along the [010], resulting from the halving of the b unit cell parameter. The Ca atoms have the same coordination environment in the structure of 3 as in 1 and 2, i.e., a distorted square antiprism built by 8 O atoms with Ca–O ranging between 2.439(2)–2.476(4) Å and an average distance equal to 2.450 Å. Besides the positional disorder of H2O molecules in the structure of 3, a splitting of the O3 site (O atom of the oxalate group) is observed (b), which is the result of symmetry operation and could be explained by cumulative effect of imposition of O7 and O4 atoms in the structure of low temperature COM modification (1 and 2).

elements.content: Recently, it was proposed that the variations of the whewellite unit cell parameters can be explained by the presence of additional H2O molecules arranged in between the Ca-bearing sheets and creating linked chains of oxalate groups. As those sites are substantially vacant and disorderly distributed, they cannot be seen in the difference Fourier synthesis maps. It is likely that phase transition from LT to HT whewellite occurs after release of these H2O molecules, whose presence in the structure causes the slight distortions leading to a doubling of the b unit cell parameter.
elements.clean_text: Recently, it was proposed that the variations of the whewellite unit cell parameters can be explained by the presence of additional H2O molecules arranged in between the Ca-bearing sheets and creating linked chains of oxalate groups. As those sites are substantially vacant and disorderly distributed, they cannot be seen in the difference Fourier synthesis maps. It is likely that phase transition from LT to HT whewellite occurs after release of these H2O molecules, whose presence in the structure causes the slight distortions leading to a doubling of the b unit cell parameter.

elements.content: Further heating of the COM single crystal sample up to 100 °C results in the release of H2O and in the transition to the novel anhydrous calcium oxalate structural type (4). Its structure is quite remarkable due to high similarity with the previous monohydrates (e). There is one crystallographically nonequivalent Ca2+ atom in the structure of 4, coordinated by seven O atoms from two nonequivalent oxalate groups (d). In comparison to the monohydrated structures of 1–3, the Ca–O bonds in 4 are shorter, as a result of the loss of one atom in the coordination sphere (Ca–O = 2.326(5)–2.461(3) Å and <Ca–O> = 2.405 Å). The Ca-centered polyhedron share the edges with three adjacent polyhedra to form a layered complex arranged parallel to (001). This resembles the projection of the monohydrated phases (d), taking into account the strong shift of one of the O atoms in the Ca-dimers caused by the release of apical H2O molecules.
elements.clean_text: Further heating of the COM single crystal sample up to 100 °C results in the release of H2O and in the transition to the novel anhydrous calcium oxalate structural type (4). Its structure is quite remarkable due to high similarity with the previous monohydrates (e). There is one crystallographically nonequivalent Ca2+ atom in the structure of 4, coordinated by seven O atoms from two nonequivalent oxalate groups (d). In comparison to the monohydrated structures of 1-3, the Ca-O bonds in 4 are shorter, as a result of the loss of one atom in the coordination sphere (Ca-O = 2.326(5)-2.461(3) Å and <Ca-O> = 2.405 Å). The Ca-centered polyhedron share the edges with three adjacent polyhedra to form a layered complex arranged parallel to (001). This resembles the projection of the monohydrated phases (d), taking into account the strong shift of one of the O atoms in the Ca-dimers caused by the release of apical H2O molecules.

elements.content: The first structural data on weddellite were obtained by Sterling, who localized the position of “zeolite” H2O molecule. Tazzoli and Domeneghetti refined the structural data and observed the disordered distribution of “zeolite” H2O molecules along the z axis within the channel. The most recent works show a significant variation in the amount of “zeolite” H2O molecules and a clear positive correlation between the latter and several crystal chemical parameters, including the a unit cell parameter.
elements.clean_text:
Weddellite Structure Evolution

The first structural data on weddellite were obtained by Sterling, who localized the position of "zeolite" H2O molecule. Tazzoli and Domeneghetti refined the structural data and observed the disordered distribution of "zeolite" H2O molecules along the z axis within the channel. The most recent works show a significant variation in the amount of "zeolite" H2O molecules and a clear positive correlation between the latter and several crystal chemical parameters, including the a unit cell parameter.

elements.content: There is one crystallographically nonequivalent Ca2+ atom in the structure of weddellite (5–10) coordinated by six O atoms of oxalate groups and two O atoms of cis-H2O molecules, to form slightly distorted square antiprisms (for instance, Ca–O = 2.326(2)–2.498(1) Å and <Ca–O> = 2.455 Å in the structure of 9). Each Ca-centered antiprism shares common O1–O1 edges with two adjacent polyhedra to form infinite chains arranged along the [001] direction. These chains are linked together via oxalate groups to form two types of channels arranged along the c axis () and different in the internal diameter. The walls of the large channel are formed by OW1 H2O molecules, while OW2 molecules are arranged within the smaller one. The diameter of the small channel could be determined as the distance between two OW2 molecules arranged at the same level and is equal to ∼3.0 Å. The diameter of the large channel is determined as the diagonal distance between OW1 atoms and is equal to ∼4.6 Å (four OW1 molecules are arranged in the plane parallel to (001)). At the center of the large channel, on the 4-fold axis, there is an additional position of “zeolite” H2O molecule that is split into two nonequivalent and essentially vacant sites (OW3 and OW31) separated by ∼0.6 Å. The sites of the OW1 and OW2 H2O molecules are fully occupied. These molecules are involved in the hydrogen bonding system with the O atoms of the oxalate groups: OW1–H1···O1 and OW2–H2···O2. The “zeolite” H2O molecules in the structures of weddellite vary from 0.13 to 0.43 p.f.u.; the resulting structural features and correlations have been discussed in detail in recent works.

These chains are linked together via oxalate groups to form two types of channels arranged along the c axis () and different in the internal diameter. The walls of the large channel are formed by OW1 H2O molecules, while OW2 molecules are arranged within the smaller one. The diameter of the small channel could be determined as the distance between two OW2 molecules arranged at the same level and is equal to ~3.0 Å. The diameter of the large channel is determined as the diagonal distance between OW1 atoms and is equal to ~4.6 Å (four OW1 molecules are arranged in the plane parallel to (001)). At the center of the large channel, on the 4-fold axis, there is an additional position of "zeolite" H2O molecule that is split into two nonequivalent and essentially vacant sites (OW3 and OW31) separated by ~0.6 Å. The sites of the OW1 and OW2 H2O molecules are fully occupied. These molecules are involved in the hydrogen bonding system with the O atoms of the oxalate groups: OW1-H1⋅⋅⋅O1 and OW2-H2⋅⋅⋅O2. The "zeolite" H2O molecules in the structures of weddellite vary from 0.13 to 0.43 p.f.u.; the resulting structural features and correlations have been discussed in detail in recent works.

elements.clean_text:
Caoxite Structure Evolution

The crystal structure of COT has been reported for the first time by Deganello et al. The structure has been subsequently described with an alternative triclinic cell setting by Basso et al. and further refined to better R-values by assigning the H atoms positions.

elements.content: There is one crystallographically nonequivalent Ca2+ atom in the structure of caoxite (11–13) coordinated by eight O atoms to form slightly distorted square antiprisms. Three of these oxygens are of nonequivalent H2O molecules, whereas the other five belong to oxalate groups. The Ca–O bond lengths correlate well with the other structures of calcium oxalates that possess the same antiprism coordination geometry (thus, Ca–O = 2.406(2)–2.538(1) Å and <Ca–O> = 2.456 Å in the structure of 13). However, the presence of three cis-H2O molecules in the coordination sphere of Ca2+ cation (g) modifies the angular parameters of the polyhedron. The crystal structure of caoxite is based on dimers of edge-sharing Ca-polyhedra, connected via oxalate groups into layered zigzag units arranged parallel to the (010) plane (). The linkage between these layers is provided by the H-bonding system only.

elements.content: Heating of the COT single crystal up to 40 °C resulted in the release of two H2O molecules and the corresponding transition to the novel calcium oxalate monohydrate (14). In this structure, the Ca2+ cations possess a quite usual distorted square antiprism coordination geometry (Ca–O = 2.420(8)–2.548(12) Å and <Ca–O> = 2.469 Å). However, the detailed analysis shows a remarkably different arrangement of its ligands in comparison to all other hydrated calcium oxalates: the oxygens of the H2O molecules, in fact, contribute to bridge two neighboring Ca atoms (c). Moreover, the linkage of the neighboring Ca-centered polyhedra occurs through the sharing of common OW1–OW1 edge. It is also worth noting that the geometry of the Ca-centered polyhedra is close to those in the structure of COD with a planar square face O1–O1–O2–O2 arranged in front of the edge of two H2O molecules (OW1–OW2 and OW1–OW1 in the structure of COD and 14, respectively). The crystal structure of 14 is based on the layered complexes of edge-shared Ca antiprisms with lens-like voids occupied by the oxalate groups that are quite similar to the sheets described in the structures of other monohydrates and anhydrous calcium oxalates. The layers are arranged parallel to (001) and linked to each other by the oxalate groups. Most likely the particular type of Ca-polyhedra linkage through the common OW1–OW1 edge results in another orientation of the oxalate groups in between the layers that is well seen on the projections of the structures along the layers (h).

elements.content: The only known to date crystal structure of anhydrous calcium oxalate (β-CaC2O4) has been solved using a combination of atomistic simulation and Rietveld method refinements from PXRD data. The calcium atoms are surrounded by seven O atoms from the oxalate groups with a geometry similar to the one found in the structure of 4. Due to the release of H2O molecules from the structure, a rearrangement of the oxalate groups occurs, and rather short O4–O4 edge-shared bonds of 2.6 Å appear between the adjacent polyhedra (O1–O1 = 3.08 Å in the structure of 4). Each Ca-centered polyhedron shares three edges with the neighbor polyhedra to form a layered complex arranged parallel to (100), whose projection is similar to the sheets in the structure of 4. The difference between the structures of anhydrous calcium oxalates is in the arrangement of “shifted vertices” within the layers caused by the release of apical H2O molecules. According to d,e, such vertices are alternating (up- or downward) within the chain of Ca polyhedra arranged along the [010] direction in the structure of 4, whereas in the structure of β-CaC2O4 the vertices are oriented only in one direction. This in turn results in a different shape of the layers (e,g): in the structure of 4 all the Ca polyhedra dimers within the layers are codirected along the [101̅] direction, whereas the layers in β-CaC2O4 are corrugated and the dimers have alternate [101] and [1̅01] orientation.
elements.clean_text:
Anhydrous Oxalate Structure

The only known to date crystal structure of anhydrous calcium oxalate (β-CaC2O4) has been solved using a combination of atomistic simulation and Rietveld method refinements from PXRD data. The calcium atoms are surrounded by seven O atoms from the oxalate groups with a geometry similar to the one found in the structure of 4. Due to the release of H2O molecules from the structure, a rearrangement of the oxalate groups occurs, and rather short O4-O4 edge-shared bonds of 2.6 Å appear between the adjacent polyhedra (O1-O1 = 3.08 Å in the structure of 4). Each Ca-centered polyhedron shares three edges with the neighbor polyhedra to form a layered complex arranged parallel to (100), whose projection is similar to the sheets in the structure of 4. The difference between the structures of anhydrous calcium oxalates is in the arrangement of "shifted vertices" within the layers caused by the release of apical H2O molecules. According to d,e, such vertices are alternating (up- or downward) within the chain of Ca polyhedra arranged along the [010] direction in the structure of 4, whereas in the structure of β-CaC2O4 the vertices are oriented only in one direction. This in turn results in a different shape of the layers (e,g): in the structure of 4 all the Ca polyhedra dimers within the layers are codirected along the [101̅] direction, whereas the layers in β-CaC2O4 are corrugated and the dimers have alternate [101] and [1̅01] orientation.

elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior and Phase Transitions

The analysis of the powder diffraction patterns obtained at room temperature revealed single COM and COD phases in the respective powder samples, while a very small amount of COM (less than 5%) was found within the COT sample (as indicated by the presence of a small diffraction maximum at around 17° 2θ; ).

elements.content: PXRD patterns of the COM sample as a function of temperature are shown in . As was already mentioned, the most noticeable difference between the classic and the HT whewellite powder data (compounds 2 and 3 and c) is the presence (or absence) of two weak peaks at around 2θ = 30°. However, only diffuse low-intensity humps are seen in the experimental patterns at the lower temperatures, with subsequent smoothing in this angular range.

elements.content: At 130 °C, a phase transition to a new phase that was assigned to the anhydrous calcium oxalate (compound 4) is clearly observable. The similarity of PXRD pattern calculated from the structural data of 4 with the card no. 00-018-0295 (PDF-2, 2016) allows us to assign the phase and our structural model of 4 to the α-CaC2O4 compound. At 150 °C the COM phase almost disappears. A further transformation to β-CaC2O4 (card no. 00-018-0296, PDF-2, 2016) starts at around 310 °C, and above 340 °C the sample does not contain the α-CaC2O4 anymore.

elements.content: It should be mentioned that recently four possible models of anhydrous calcium oxalates were proposed using quantum mechanical methods, among which one model (COA-IV) is very close to the structural model of compound 4. It is of interest that Zhao W. et al. have suggested another (COA-III) model to be the α-CaC2O4. This inconsistency could be easily explained by the difficult comparison of nearly similar calculated diffraction patterns with the not so clear experimental one. The assignment of compound 4 to the first among the anhydrous phases is obvious, since such transition was detected in situ while heating the single crystal of COM, but on the other hand, we could expect the rest of the predicted models appear as additional transitional architectures between the α- and β- or β- and γ-CaC2O4.

elements.content: As clearly seen from the graphs of the COM unit-cell parameters as a function of temperature (Figure S2), the essential change in the temperature dependence character starts at 70 °C. Similar inflection points around 70 °C are observed if the powder patterns are indexed in the unit cell of HT whewellite modification (3). Combining the SC and PXRD data, it is most likely that the transition from LT to HT whewellite occurs in the 55–75 °C range. Thus, indexing of COM powder diffraction patterns have been performed in the following temperature ranges: whewellite 23–70 °C, HT whewellite 70–120 °C, α-CaC2O4 150–300 °C (Table S2, Figures S2–S4).

elements.content: According to the theory of thermal behavior, the maximal thermal expansion should be along the direction of the weakest bonding. Taking into account the layered structural motif of whewellite and its thermal derivatives, one could expect the highest expansion in the direction perpendicular to the sheets of Ca-bearing polyhedra. However, the linkage of sheets via oxalate groups and the oblique symmetry of the lattice modify the thermal behavior. The maximal expansion is observed toward the bisector of the β angle as the result of the shear stress of the layers (a–f). The strongest contraction occurs perpendicular to the (101̅) plane and is due to the orthogonalization of the monoclinic angle. The thermal behavior of the HT whewellite phase is governed by layers shifting followed by the release of structural water, which decreases the interlayer spacing. Further diagonal expansion/contraction in the structure of α-CaC2O4 results in the undulation of the Ca-bearing layers and almost final orthogonalization of the structure (β = 90.24(2) Å), as it is shown in g.

elements.content: The powder pattern of weddellite (COD) remains almost unchanged up to 140 °C (a). At 150 °C a significant peak shift and a decrease of all peak intensities occur, resulting in the transformation of COD to the anhydrous phase. Although the diffraction patterns collected at 160 °C and higher temperatures do not contain sharp and regular reflections, the closest match of the profiles is observed for the anhydrous phase of compound 4. It is of great interest that during long-term storage at room temperature, weddellite transforms to whewellite. The same result was obtained during another experiment in which a COD sample was kept in the oven at 60 °C for 3 h; then a PXRD pattern was collected. After 3 cycles of “heating–collecting data”, the COM phase appeared within the sample, and after 10 cycles the sample became pure monohydrate. Thus, during fast heating, the structure of COD could remain stable up to unusually high values, and it would instantly transform to the phase expectedly stable at that temperature range (for instance, in our case these are 150 °C and α-CaC2O4).

elements.content: The trend of the unit-cell parameters of COD as a function of temperature is shown in b. Three temperature zones (23–60, 70–105, and 110–126 °C) can be evidenced. In the first region, a significant decrease of a and V is observed, followed by a slight increase of c due to the mechanical compression of the framework channels resulting from the release of “zeolite” H2O molecules from the structure. In the second temperature range, the structure goes through an almost isotropic thermal expansion. In the third range, a sharp drop in the values of all cell parameters indicates the beginning of a structural rearrangement as a consequence of the framework H2O molecules release. At the same time, this process passes with the preservation of the weddellite structural type. And starting from the 130 °C there is a catastrophic change in the structure due to complete dehydration followed by its transition into the anhydrous α-CaC2O4 modification, which is completely finished at around 150 °C.

The thermal behavior of weddellite varies from being essentially anisotropic between 23 and 60 °C to being almost isotropic in the 70–105 °C range. The anisotropy in the first interval is only due to the release of H2O molecules; therefore, the second interval could be regarded as the actual thermal behavior of the weddellite framework. The difference in behavior along a and c has to be sought in the bonding pattern of the material. Strong bonds characterize the edge-sharing Ca-centered polyhedra chains and their arrangement along the [001] direction, while less strong bonds (arranged along the [100] and [010]) involving oxalate groups provide the linkage of chains with the neighbor ones, and are thus responsible for the compression and stretching of the structure.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of the COT sample as a function of temperature are shown in . The most significant visible changes occur at 65 and 145 °C. At 65 °C the sample transforms to the COM phase, and at around 145 °C full dehydration to α-CaC2O4 occurs, as seen from the splitting of peaks at 2θ = 17.5 and 35°. Less noticeable changes take place at around 40 °C when convergence and unification of split reflections occur (for instance, at 18.5°2θ). This is the result of the transition of COT phase to the novel calcium oxalate monohydrate (compound 14), whose structure was solved using the SCXRD method and reported herein for the first time.

elements.content: The existence of a phase transition at around 40 °C is also confirmed by the evolution of the unit-cell parameters as a function of temperature (Figure S5). Distinct alteration of the trend lines after 40 °C is a consequence of COT transformation to the monohydrate phase with the release of two H2O molecules from the unit cell. However, this transition is not instantaneous and lasts up to 65 °C when the sample became a monophasic HT COM modification. It is of interest that the most significant leap is attributed to the a, c, and β unit-cell parameters, which correspond to the layer within the structure of COT. On the other hand, the b parameter that is responsible for the H-bonding between the calcium oxalate sheets retains the same linear temperature dependence. Most likely, it indicates the preservation of the interlayer interactions character and distances when the H2O molecules are replaced by the oxalate groups as a linker between the Ca-polyhedra sheets. The equations describing COT unit-cell values alteration with heating in the 23–40 °C range are given in Table S4. The eigenvalues of thermal expansion coefficients are listed in . Visualized figures of thermal expansion coefficients are shown in .

elements.content: The maximal thermal expansion is observed in the direction close to (010), which corresponds to the H-bonding system between the rarefied zigzag layered complexes. At the same time, thermal contraction is observed within the layer, which is well explained by the straightening of the layer following with convergence of Ca-polyhedra dimers. Such motion could be regarded as the precursor to the formation of dense layers in the structures of COM phases.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal behavior of COM and COD phases at a temperature range below 0 °C another type of camera was used, which requires the powder sample to be under a vacuum to prevent icing while cooling down the system with the nitrogen gas flow. Such experimental feature made an adjustment to the diffraction data that apparently results in the instant release of H2O molecules from the system right after the transitioning process starts, which in turn shifts all the temperature dependencies to much lower values (Figure S6). Thus, the phase transition from LT to HT whewellite modification occurs around −30 °C. The α-CaC2O4 phase begins to form starting from 55 °C with ending of transformation at around 85–90 °C. It is of interest that transformation of the COD sample occurs almost immediately to an anhydrous α-CaC2O4 phase at the same temperature range of 85–90 °C, but the crystallinity of the sample is much worse than in all other HT and LT experiments, which is most likely due to a drastic alteration of powder after release of all water molecules (Table S6; Figures S7 and S8).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the thermal behavior of COM and COD phases at a temperature range below 0 °C another type of camera was used, which requires the powder sample to be under a vacuum to prevent icing while cooling down the system with the nitrogen gas flow. Such experimental feature made an adjustment to the diffraction data that apparently results in the instant release of H2O molecules from the system right after the transitioning process starts, which in turn shifts all the temperature dependencies to much lower values (Figure S6). Thus, the phase transition from LT to HT whewellite modification occurs around -30 °C. The α-CaC2O4 phase begins to form starting from 55 °C with ending of transformation at around 85-90 °C. It is of interest that transformation of the COD sample occurs almost immediately to an anhydrous α-CaC2O4 phase at the same temperature range of 85-90 °C, but the crystallinity of the sample is much worse than in all other HT and LT experiments, which is most likely due to a drastic alteration of powder after release of all water molecules (Table S6; Figures S7 and S8).

elements.content: It is worth noting that the correlation of our XRD data with the results of TGA and DSC experiments show quite good agreement for the transition of calcium oxalates to the anhydrous modification, whereas decomposition of COD and COT samples occurs at ∼20 °C lower temperatures than it is described herein. These features could be explained by the various heating rates, but it depends strongly on the different experimental atmospheres. Our study shows a significant influence of air or vacuum (HT and LT, respectively) atmosphere on the dehydration-driven phase transitions. A similar correlation with the reduction of phase transition temperatures is observed in TGA experiments under N2 flow. Moreover, such subtle transformations, as the transition from caoxite to the novel COM modification (14), have not been previously detected.

These features could be explained by the various heating rates, but it depends strongly on the different experimental atmospheres. Our study shows a significant influence of air or vacuum (HT and LT, respectively) atmosphere on the dehydration-driven phase transitions. A similar correlation with the reduction of phase transition temperatures is observed in TGA experiments under N2 flow. Moreover, such subtle transformations, as the transition from caoxite to the novel COM modification (14), have not been previously detected.

elements.content: In order to analyze the phase evolution within the family of calcium oxalate compounds, we studied their complexity in terms of the information-based approach developed in refs and implemented in refs . The structural complexity is quantitatively estimated as the Shannon information content per atom (I G) and per unit cell (I G,total) using the following equations: I G = − ∑ i = 1 k p i ⁡ log 2 ⁡ p i ( bits / atom ) I G , t o t a l = − ν I G = − ν ∑ i = 1 k p i ⁡ log 2 ⁡ p i ( bits / cell ) where k is the number of different crystallographic orbits (independent crystallographic Wyckoff sites) in the structure, and p i is the random choice probability for an atom from the ith crystallographic orbit, that is p i = m i / v where m i is a multiplicity of a crystallographic orbit (i.e., the number of atoms of a specific Wyckoff site in the reduced unit cell), and v is the total number of atoms in the reduced unit cell.

Structural Complexity Analysis

In order to analyze the phase evolution within the family of calcium oxalate compounds, we studied their complexity in terms of the information-based approach developed in refs  and implemented in refs . The structural complexity is quantitatively estimated as the Shannon information content per atom (I G) and per unit cell (I G,total) using the following equations: 1       I   G   = -    ∑   i = 1   k      p   i   ⁡   log   2   ⁡   p   i       ( bits / atom )       2       I   G , t o t a l   = - ν   I   G   = - ν    ∑   i = 1   k      p   i   ⁡   log   2   ⁡   p   i       ( bits / cell )     where k is the number of different crystallographic orbits (independent crystallographic Wyckoff sites) in the structure, and p  i  is the random choice probability for an atom from the ith crystallographic orbit, that is 7      p i  =  m i  / v    where m  i  is a multiplicity of a crystallographic orbit (i.e., the number of atoms of a specific Wyckoff site in the reduced unit cell), and v is the total number of atoms in the reduced unit cell.

elements.content: An overall trend of the information-based approach shows that complexities of structures formed in the latter stages of crystallization are higher than those for the phases growing in the initial stages. Changes in hydration state could distort the overall complexity behavior; therefore, the reliable correlation could be obtained for compounds with the same or very close chemical composition (e.g., polymorphs).
elements.clean_text: An overall trend of the information-based approach shows that complexities of structures formed in the latter stages of crystallization are higher than those for the phases growing in the initial stages. Changes in hydration state could distort the overall complexity behavior; therefore, the reliable correlation could be obtained for compounds with the same or very close chemical composition (e.g., polymorphs).

elements.content: The information-based complexity parameters for the structurally characterized calcium oxalate compounds are given in . Complexity parameters have been calculated using the TOPOS package. It should be noted that to obtain complexity parameters, the split and disordered sites were counted as single, the positions of all atoms (including H) were taken into account, and all H atoms of the “zeolitic” H2O molecules were assigned based on the geometry and occupancy of the corresponding O site.

The observed values demonstrate that structural complexity of whewellite (1–2) is much higher than that in the other structures. Such a result is in agreement with the general trend, especially considering that whewellite is the most common calcium oxalate in nature and most easily obtained phase within laboratory studies. I G,total complexity parameters calculated for COD and COT phases are much lower than that for whewellite, but at the same time they are significantly higher than those for other calcium oxalate structures, which also fits the structural complexity theory and once again explains the discovery in nature of only these three phases.

Such a result is in agreement with the general trend, especially considering that whewellite is the most common calcium oxalate in nature and most easily obtained phase within laboratory studies. I G,total complexity parameters calculated for COD and COT phases are much lower than that for whewellite, but at the same time they are significantly higher than those for other calcium oxalate structures, which also fits the structural complexity theory and once again explains the discovery in nature of only these three phases.

elements.content: The topological similarities of the calcium oxalate structural units, the results of thermal studies, and the information-based complexity calculations suggest a scheme of dehydration-driven evolution within the calcium oxalate family (). It is well-known that the reduction of H2O content in the structure increases the dimensionality of the structural unit. Thus, the transformation of both the Ca dimers-based structure in caoxite and the microporous framework made of Ca-polyhedra chains in weddellite to a much denser layered architecture in the structures of COM phases is quite evident.
elements.clean_text:
Structural and Chemical Evolution of Calcium Oxalate Compounds

The topological similarities of the calcium oxalate structural units, the results of thermal studies, and the information-based complexity calculations suggest a scheme of dehydration-driven evolution within the calcium oxalate family (). It is well-known that the reduction of H2O content in the structure increases the dimensionality of the structural unit. Thus, the transformation of both the Ca dimers-based structure in caoxite and the microporous framework made of Ca-polyhedra chains in weddellite to a much denser layered architecture in the structures of COM phases is quite evident.

elements.content: Scheme of chemical and structural evolution of calcium oxalates. Legend: red arrows = heating; blue arrows = cooling.
elements.clean_text: 11  Scheme of chemical and structural evolution of calcium oxalates. Legend: red arrows = heating; blue arrows = cooling.

elements.content: Whewellite transformations stand out as the main branch of transitions among the calcium oxalates. All of these transitions are reversible and return back to whewellite at room temperature and atmospheric conditions. This explains the natural prevalence of whewellite over weddellite and caoxite. The transformation of whewellite to a high-temperature modification is in agreement with basic crystal chemical principles: a temperature rise usually results in ordering and in the increase of symmetry. Next in the row is α-CaC2O4, which has the closest structural architecture to whewellite. The geometry of the Ca-centered polyhedra is inherited from COM: the water release leaves a gap in the coordination sphere, which is compensated by a shortening of the Ca–O distances and, partially, by a slight shift and rotation of the oxalate groups; the rest of the geometry is almost unchanged.
elements.clean_text: Whewellite transformations stand out as the main branch of transitions among the calcium oxalates. All of these transitions are reversible and return back to whewellite at room temperature and atmospheric conditions. This explains the natural prevalence of whewellite over weddellite and caoxite. The transformation of whewellite to a high-temperature modification is in agreement with basic crystal chemical principles: a temperature rise usually results in ordering and in the increase of symmetry. Next in the row is α-CaC2O4, which has the closest structural architecture to whewellite. The geometry of the Ca-centered polyhedra is inherited from COM: the water release leaves a gap in the coordination sphere, which is compensated by a shortening of the Ca-O distances and, partially, by a slight shift and rotation of the oxalate groups; the rest of the geometry is almost unchanged.

elements.content: Depending on the heating rate, COD could transform to three different phases. At room temperature, COD transforms to whewellite, but the kinetics seems slow (according to our observations, pure COD samples after 4 years of storage contain, on average, about 30% of COM). At the same time, the porous framework of weddellite appears to be unexpectedly strong, so it could survive even up to 140 °C, whereupon it instantly transforms to a phase from the whewellite row, stable in that temperature range (for instance, at 150 °C it is α-CaC2O4).
elements.clean_text: Depending on the heating rate, COD could transform to three different phases. At room temperature, COD transforms to whewellite, but the kinetics seems slow (according to our observations, pure COD samples after 4 years of storage contain, on average, about 30% of COM). At the same time, the porous framework of weddellite appears to be unexpectedly strong, so it could survive even up to 140 °C, whereupon it instantly transforms to a phase from the whewellite row, stable in that temperature range (for instance, at 150 °C it is α-CaC2O4).

elements.content: The rarest mineral among the calcium oxalates, caoxite, has the lowest transition temperature. COT first transforms to the new calcium oxalate monohydrate described in this work. The new phase is however metastable: upon cooling it transforms into whewellite and upon heating into HT-whewellite, from which further transformation might occur.
elements.clean_text: The rarest mineral among the calcium oxalates, caoxite, has the lowest transition temperature. COT first transforms to the new calcium oxalate monohydrate described in this work. The new phase is however metastable: upon cooling it transforms into whewellite and upon heating into HT-whewellite, from which further transformation might occur.

elements.content: In this paper, we have reported a rather complicated evolution of the structure and composition of crystalline calcium oxalates. The reduction of H2O content in the structures increases dimensionality from dimers and chains to the layered structural units and from rarefied to denser sheets within the compounds whose structures are based on the 2D units. Whewellite (calcium oxalate monohydrate) should be regarded as the most stable crystalline phase at the atmospheric ambient conditions within the whole family of calcium oxalates. Other known mineral species (weddellite and caoxite) transform to whewellite during dehydration-driven phase transition caused by time and/or heating. Moreover, we can assume that the majority of natural COD and COT samples have been quite recently crystallized unless they were kept cold to prevent the dehydration processes. While studying the phase transitions pathways within the calcium oxalate family, we structurally characterized two crystalline compounds for the first time (α-CaC2O4 and CaC2O4·H2O), among which the novel COM modification was obtained for the first time as well. The oxalates tend to undergo an essentially anisotropic alteration with heating: the highest expansion is observed along the direction of hydrogen bonds, while the lowest expansion (and even contraction) occurs due to the displacement of neighbor layered complexes toward each other and orthogonalization of the monoclinic angles. The most complicated behavior is observed for the COD phase, which first undergoes a significant compression of the “zeolite” channels due to the release of weakly bonded interchannel H2O molecules, and then switches to an almost isotropic trend. The comparison of the results of TGA and XRD experiments shows that the dehydration-driven phase transition occurs over a relatively large temperature range and is highly dependent on the heating rates, so the transition could take a few minutes at the highest temperatures or could last years at lower ones. Finally, we would like to emphasize the particular importance of the structural and chemical evolution studies of calcium oxalates, as their phase transitions occur at temperatures typical of the human body and can therefore have a significant effect on health.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we have reported a rather complicated evolution of the structure and composition of crystalline calcium oxalates. The reduction of H2O content in the structures increases dimensionality from dimers and chains to the layered structural units and from rarefied to denser sheets within the compounds whose structures are based on the 2D units. Whewellite (calcium oxalate monohydrate) should be regarded as the most stable crystalline phase at the atmospheric ambient conditions within the whole family of calcium oxalates. Other known mineral species (weddellite and caoxite) transform to whewellite during dehydration-driven phase transition caused by time and/or heating. Moreover, we can assume that the majority of natural COD and COT samples have been quite recently crystallized unless they were kept cold to prevent the dehydration processes. While studying the phase transitions pathways within the calcium oxalate family, we structurally characterized two crystalline compounds for the first time (α-CaC2O4 and CaC2O4⋅H2O), among which the novel COM modification was obtained for the first time as well. The oxalates tend to undergo an essentially anisotropic alteration with heating: the highest expansion is observed along the direction of hydrogen bonds, while the lowest expansion (and even contraction) occurs due to the displacement of neighbor layered complexes toward each other and orthogonalization of the monoclinic angles. The most complicated behavior is observed for the COD phase, which first undergoes a significant compression of the "zeolite" channels due to the release of weakly bonded interchannel H2O molecules, and then switches to an almost isotropic trend. The comparison of the results of TGA and XRD experiments shows that the dehydration-driven phase transition occurs over a relatively large temperature range and is highly dependent on the heating rates, so the transition could take a few minutes at the highest temperatures or could last years at lower ones. Finally, we would like to emphasize the particular importance of the structural and chemical evolution studies of calcium oxalates, as their phase transitions occur at temperatures typical of the human body and can therefore have a significant effect on health.
